Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is acknowledged as a significant half-reaction in water splitting for long-term hydrogen generation. In this context, developing effective catalysts for OER has thus far been the subject of considerable effort. Owing to their high activity and stability as inexpensive OER electrocatalysts, in addition to non-metals and oxide metals-based oxides considered the standard, metals have attracted a growing interest. The design and synthesis of all types of metal for water oxidation electrocatalysis are succinctly outlined in this review. Besides, some typical uses for these metals are noted. Moreover, the outlook and development trends are explored. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal based-electrocatalyst Eco-friendly electrocatalyst Oxygen evolution reaction Water splitting Hydrogen generation Data availability All data has been reported in the article. 1 Introduction The environment and energy are two of today's most pressing issues [1,2]. Energy demand has been rising quickly on a global scale, and it is predicted that it will double within the next 15 years [3]. Nevertheless, fossil fuels, whose sources are limited, provide the majority of the world's energy [4]. Consequently, producing energy from renewables has been viewed as a promising strategy for significantly lowering our reliance on highly pollutant energy sources [5,6]. The most straightforward, effective, and dependable categories of the various energy systems controlled by electrochemical reactions include water splitting, metal-air batteries, and fuel cells. In addition to oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and/or hydrogen evaluation reaction (HER), water oxidation reaction or oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is the key reaction for all of these systems to carry out their reversible processes [7,8]. Proton/electron-coupled processes are used in OER to create molecular oxygen [9]. For example, two H2O molecules are oxidized in neutral and acidic environments to produce four protons (H+) and an O2 molecule. In contrast, in basic environments, OH− groups are oxidized to produce H2O and O2. The equilibrium half-cell potentials (E°a) for OER at 1 atm and 25°C are listed below [10,11]: (1) 4 O H − ↔ 2 H 2 O ( l ) + O 2 ( g ) + 4 e E a o = 0.404 V Alkaline solution (2) 2 H 2 O ( l ) ↔ 4 H + + O 2 ( g ) + 4 e E a o = 1.23 V Acidic solution Despite their moderate reactivity with OER, metal-based materials are currently ranked first, considering their stability for wide pH intervals [12,13]. Nevertheless, the high prices and limited availability of particular metals pose the most significant obstacles to their practical applications [14]. Much study has been put into finding substitute materials with higher OER activity. Many different types of catalysts are being developed right now, including those based on noble metals, carbon-based materials, alloys, oxides, and oxy-hydroxides of earth-abundant metals [15,16]. Even though modern research has produced numerous high-performance catalysts, noble-metal-based catalysts have not been able to replace them. This review article summarizes the difficulties, issues, and new developments pertaining to OER and the solutions to these problems using appropriate examples from the literature. This evaluation offers a figure of merit (standards) for OER activity and stability under typical circumstances. The importance of this reaction is also demonstrated through its use in devices like fuel cells, metal-air batteries, and water splitting. Besides, the outlook and development trends are explored. 2 Transition metal carbides in electrocatalytic OER Due to their excellent physical and chemical properties, transition metal carbides (TMC) can be effectively applied for the electrocatalytic oxidation of water. Their impressive qualities include high coefficients for electrical conductivity, mechanical stability, and good corrosion resistance [17]. As a result, carbide nanomaterials have made significant progress despite the difficulties inherent in their production and application on a large scale [18]. This section details several typical carbides and their recent use for electrocatalytic OER [10]. 2.1 Iron carbides for electrocatalytic OER Non-noble transition metals have many advantages over noble metal materials, including inexpensive cost, plentiful resources, and reduced toxicity [19]. According to the latest reports, transition metal carbides possess "platinum-like" electrical properties and exceptional catalytic activity [20]. In addition, iron is perhaps the most plentiful metallic element on earth; therefore, iron carbide has a vast array of potential applications in electrocatalytic OER (Fig. 1 ) [21]. Nevertheless, iron carbide catalysts' poor stability and electrical conductivity result in diminished catalytic performance. In light of this, producing a composite material consisting of iron carbide and a conductive carrier is the most effective method for dealing with the abovementioned issues [22]. Furthermore, employing a catalyst that can meet the binding energy requirements between reactive intermediates and the catalytic surface is essential for a process to be successful [23]. Multicomponent materials containing energetic carbides and graphene-like carbon can benefit from the passage of electrolyte ions [24] and the adsorption of reactants due to their large surface areas and high concentrations of active sites [25]. Fe3C NPs were encapsulated in porous carbon nitride [26], graphite [27], nitrogen-functionalized carbon nanofibers [28], and N-doped carbon nanotubes [29], where the porous nature can enhance surface area and speed up charge transfer, hence enhancing OER activity. For example, Zhu et al. [20] developed a Fe3C NSs@Ni foam (NF) nanocomposite by employing a one-step solvothermal and annealing technique. This strategy enabled the researchers to create a nanocomposite with the desired properties by exposing more active sites by the nanosheet structure of Fe3C. In contrast, the distinctive 3D structure of Fe3C@NF endowed it with a large surface area, excellent electrical conductivity, and a greater number of active sites. As a consequence, the OER activity displayed by the Fe3C@NF nanocomposite was astounding. It has also been constructed to contain Fe/Fe3C NPs in a hierarchical framework within N-doped graphene [30]. The nanostructure exhibited comparable OER activity to that of RuO2 catalysts [31]. Despite impressive progress, there is still a long way to go before the new iron carbides with enhanced OER activity can be used in industrial applications. 2.2 Cobalt carbides for electrocatalytic OER Cobalt carbides have been used in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis reactions [33]. However, despite a few papers discussing OER, cobalt carbides continue to suffer from high overpotential due to their poor stability in harsh electrolytes and limited intrinsic activity [34]. In this context, bimetallic compounds are considered particularly relevant candidates due to their ability to change the active center's electronic structure and reveal additional active sites [35]. Consequently, bimetallic carbide materials are considered as prospective OER catalysts [36]. For example, Tang et al. developed a bimetallic carbide with a Co/Mo composition that possesses exceptional stability, a low overpotential in the range of 260 mV, and a low Tafel slope [37]. In addition, heteroatom doping, an efficient technique for modifying the electrical catalysts structure, has extensively produced many catalysts. For instance, Zhang et al. have described a straightforward method of doping cobalt carbide with lower electronegative vanadium (V), which causes many flaws in the cobalt carbide lattice [38]. V0.28Co0.72C/carbon nanofibers mainly exhibit the greatest electrocatalytic water splitting performance with the appropriate doping quantity, decomposing at 1.47 V and 10 mA/cm2 current density. Cobalt's transformation into a local negative center due to the transfer of electron density from V to Co is primarily responsible for the observed substantial raise in total water splitting. A N, B-codoping Co3C catalyst with a 358 mV overpotential and significant OER activity has been reported by Ma et al. [39]. It also demonstrated increased stabilities. Besides, the porous structure helps the catalyst produce a higher OER activity since it exposes more active sites and has a higher surface area. For instance, He's group used a two-step process to create a hierarchical porous Co3C/Co-N-C/G nanomaterial [40]. Due to the increased number of exposed active sites and the synergistic interactions between all of the components, the catalyst in its as-prepared state has demonstrated excellent OER efficiency. 2.3 Nickel carbides for electrocatalytic OER Nickel carbides are an attractive candidate for use as an electrocatalyst for OER because they have a higher electrical conductivity and are earth-abundant. Due to its superior physicochemical characteristics, including its high chemical stability and conductivity, Ni3C has attracted much attention among different nickel carbides [41]. As an OER catalyst, a Ni3C/C composite demonstrated high HER and OER bifunctional catalytic activity [42]. Optimizing electrocatalytic performance is necessary for producing nickel carbide OER catalysts. For example, Qin et al. demonstrated and reported the hierarchical Ni/Ni3C core/shell nanospheres. This structure has more active sites exposed, and as a result, it has demonstrated remarkable electrocatalytic activity with an OER potential as low as 350 mV at 10 mA/cm2 [43]. To improve Ni/Ni3C catalysts, Hao et al. developed Ni3C/N-doped carbon nanoflakes with a shape and composition that can be regulated by changing the synthesis parameters (Fig. 2 ) [44]. The resulting Ni3C/NC nanoflakes had a remarkable electrocatalytic performance with a low overpotential of 309 mV. The Ni/Ni3C-NCNT material developed by Dong et al. had N-doped carbon nanotubes uniformly dispersed along the NCNT wall. Because of its distinct composition and structure, the sample demonstrated enhanced OER catalytic activity with a low overpotential of 277 mV [45]. In the process of electrocatalysis, the adsorption/desorption energies of intermediates are affected by various valence states of the active center of the catalyst. As a result, making adjustments to the valence in a logical manner is an excellent way to enhance performance. The valence state of a catalyst can be efficiently controlled by adding metals with various levels of electronegativity. Zinc, for instance, can alter the electrical properties of the bimetallic Ni3ZnC0.7, improving OER activity [46]. According to Yang et al., nickel carbide is mixed with a high-valence metal (Molybdenum) to create a bimetallic Mo6Ni6C catalyst. During the catalysis, high-valence Mo6+ combined with Ni species, and C was inserted at the atomic level into the MoNi array. This effectively increased conductivity and exposed more active sites. Therefore, the bimetallic Mo6Ni6C demonstrated astonishing OER activity with a current density of 10 mA/cm2 and an overpotential of 190 mV [47]. The electron structure of catalysts can be altered by heteroatom doping, which can also encourage electron transfer and improve catalytic performance. In contrast to pure Ni3C, Jia et al. produced a co-doped Ni3C/C composite, that demonstrated exceptional OER catalytic capability [48]. Additionally, catalysts with high index facets typically have better OER catalytic performance. As a result, Yang has developed high-index faceted NiC0.2 NSs on Ni-coated Cu foil. An overpotential of 228 mV at 10 mA/cm2 indicates that the catalyst, in its as-prepared state, exhibited both high catalytic activity and long-term stability [49]. 2.4 Other metal carbides for electrocatalytic OER Among all carbides, molybdenum/tungsten carbides have previously been investigated as HER catalysts. However, during the OER process, the metals in carbides are changed into OER-active species [50]. Therefore, there is still much room for improvement in order to become a high-activity OER catalyst. For instance, the HER and OER performances of the B, N-codoped Mo2C NPs encapsulated on B, N-codoped carbon network are promising [51]. A MoS2/Mo2C hybrid structure was proposed by Tiwari et al., and it demonstrated superior ORR and OER performance compared to other molybdenum carbide catalysts with overpotential of 280 mV at 10 mA/cm2. The high ORR and OER activity are caused by the lattice strain in the structure [52]. Comparable to platinum's d-electronic structure, tungsten carbides have been extensively employed as HER catalysts [53]. Because of their exceptional physicochemical properties, MXenes are intriguing materials for various energy storage devices as well as the process of water splitting. Some of these characteristics include porosity, high electrical conductivity, and stability. For instance, Pang et al. [54] suggested using electrochemical etching to synthesize MXenes. When applied to water oxidation, the material demonstrates catalytic performance comparable to commercial IrO2. However, due to the constraints imposed by the traditional synthesis method, the resulting 2D MXenes have a high density and a propensity to stack on top of one another. This leads to an inefficient transfer of mass and inactive sites for electrocatalytic water splitting. Assembling 2D MXenes into a 3D structure is one method for solving this issue. To create the 3D microflower structures made of molybdenum carbide (Mo2CTx), Wang et al. developed a pyrolysis technique and surface engineering [55]. Due to its exceptional structural qualities, Mo2CTx demonstrated powerful electrocatalytic OER activity with a 180 mV overpotential and a current density of 10 mA/cm2 (Fig. 3 ) [56]. MXenes are also suitable carrier materials because of their high surface area and electronegative surfaces. These characteristics may charge the catalyst's electronic structure and maximize the material's activity. OER catalysts based on manganese carbide have also been researched. For example, Streb et al. developed a hybrid containing metal oxides, carbides, and CNTs by employing Mn/V oxide as a precursor [57]. 3 Advanced metal boride electrocatalysts for OER Transition metal borides (TMBs) represent a novel class of catalysts. Variants that include Co, Fe, Ni, W, Mo, and V. Mo-based borides [58] are primarily employed as HER catalysts. In contrast, other TMBs are used as OER, HER, and bifunctional electrocatalysts [59,60]. TMBs have only recently been utilized as OER catalysts and have undergone a complex transformation from simple to intricate. . This process began with monometallic, bimetallic, and trimetallic borides and culminated in various metal boride-supported compounds. In addition, the boron-based family of water evolution reaction catalysts and its efficiency has recently undergone significant boron enrichment [61,62]. 3.1 Monometallic borides The first type of TMBs investigated was monometallic borides. A monometallic boride is a pure boride that only contains one metal and is not hybridized with any carrier. NaBH4 has frequently been applied as a reducing agent and boron source in producing monometallic borides through chemical reduction techniques. For instance, to make M-B (M: Co, Fe, Ni), a NaBH4 solution is gently added to the metal salt solution. These borides, such as Co2B [63], Fe2B [64], and NixB [65], are amorphous if not exposed to any other treatment. Some of the following processes are crucial to enhance their OER performance further. (i) High-temperature annealing As with NixB-300 [65], Co2B-500 [63], and FeB2-600 [60], the annealing procedure can alter the electronic structure, which improves the OER performance. (ii) Making use of various solvents. By reducing FeCl2 with LiBH4 in refluxing THF, Li et al. [60] created FeB2-600, a remarkable electrocatalyst for total water splitting. In contrast, Fe2B [64] particles were made in an aqueous solution and had significantly lower catalytic activity than NixB [65] and Co2B [63]. (iii) Oxidation therapy. By oxidizing FeB2, Wang et al. [66] created a Fe-B-O@FeB2 OER catalyst, demonstrating astounding activity for OER in alkaline electrolytes. Similar to this, Wang et al. [67] produced a final product of Co-B-O as a catalyst using a chemical reduction approach with THF as a solvent and an oxidation process. It is essential to be aware of the fact that the catalyst displays different characteristics depending on the working electrode material, which can be either glassy carbon (GC) electrode, fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glass, or nickel foam (NF) [68]. NF has an innate activity for OER, which is anticipated to significantly boost efficiency. However, it is challenging to accurately quantify the true surface area of NF, which causes significant errors in computing current density. For example, the catalyst supported on GC had a potential of 1.61 V. In contrast, the Co2B-500 produced by Justus Masa et al. and supported on FTO glass had a potential of 1.68 V at 10 mA/cm2 current density. This distinction is almost certainly attributable to the fact that GC glass possesses a higher charge transfer rate compared with FTO glass. Therefore, it is not fair to comparatively assess the accuracy of catalysts supported on various substrates [63]. Because metal boride has an intrinsic catalytic activity, it makes a suitable OER catalyst. Several methods can be used to improve performance to bring catalytic efficiency in line with current standards. First, this is because, in general, amorphous materials have lower electrical conductivity than their crystalline counterparts [63]. Second, oxidation of the surface may reveal more active sites. Thirdly, one way to boost catalytic activity is to use a conductive material as the working electrode. This will allow for greater current transfer. In conclusion, the various methods of product preparation have the potential to significantly impact the product's composition and properties [61]. 3.2 Polymetallic borides The definition of a polymetallic boride is the same as that of a monometallic boride: it is a pure boride that contains multiple metals but is not hybridized with any carrier [69]. Likewise, polymetallic borides, which are also amorphous if not given any additional treatment, can be made by gradually incorporating an aqueous solution containing NaBH4 into the mixed metal salt solution. Bimetallic and trimetallic borides have been used as OER catalysts thus far. However, the unary metal complexes' electronic structure can be altered by adding a second metal element, significantly improving their catalytic efficacy [70]. It has been hypothesized that this is due to several factors, including but not limited to: increased charge transfer between different materials, altered electronic structures, and decreased kinetic energy barriers [71]. Numerous studies have shown that the chemically reduced form of Fe-B in aqueous solution possesses poor catalytic properties; however, it has been established beyond a reasonable doubt that the incorporation of Fe significantly boosts the activity of Co- and Ni-based OER catalysts. Since adding Fe alters the electronic structure of monometallic borides [72], it also acts as the OER process' active site [64]. Additionally, it has been demonstrated that adding Fe can help the intermediate MOOH develop and stay stable [71]. According to Chen et al. [64], Co2FeB on a Cu substrate exhibits a 42 mV lower overpotential than Co-B. Additionally, Liu et al. [71] observed that the NiFeB catalysts had a good impact on activity than Ni-B and Fe-B. Besides, they have shown how various substrate materials affect catalytic performance. Other elements can also promote one another, as shown by the increased catalytic performance of the Co-Mo-B [73], FeCo2.3NiB [74], Ni-Co-B [75], and NiCoBOx [76] catalysts over those of the corresponding metal borides. It is important to note that Han et al.'s innovative [59] self-templating method involved reducing Co2Ni precursors with NaBH4 to produce Co-Ni-B, which was then coated with V via atomic layer deposition (ALD). The result was V-doped Co-Ni-B(VCNB) (Fig. 4 ). Combining DFT calculations with observations also demonstrated the distinctive functions of the metals in VCNB. It has revealed that Co and B are active sites, Ni modified the surface electronic structure, and V acts as a charge carrier transporter and provider. As a result, one strategy that could enhance the OER catalytic efficiency of the TMBs is the use of synergistic effects on various metals. 3.3 Metal boride-supported compound Recently, monometallic and polymetallic borides have demonstrated interesting OER or HER activities. However, the TMBs have low conductivity and instability and are easily agglomerated. Therefore, attaching them to conductive substrates is a good way to address these issues [77]. The strong electrical conductivity and vast surface area of carbon nanomaterials like graphene, porous carbon, and CNT make them attractive substrate materials for various catalysts [78]. As a direct consequence, TMBs loaded in a variety of carbon materials have undergone significant development over the past few years. Examples include Co2B-500/NG, a bifunctional catalyst created by doping Co2B-500 with nitrogen, and CoB@NCNTs, an extremely efficient oxygen electrocatalyst. Due to its electronegativity properties, graphene oxide (GO) is especially capable of adsorbing cations [79]. After that, NaBH4 reduces M2+/GO to create TMBs/rGO [80]. As shown in Fig. 5 , the TMBs/rGO hybrid is created using a room temperature procedure. Recently, Chen et al. [77] functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes using negative charge as support and created a bifunctional catalyst (NixB/f-MWCNTs). Guo et al. have employed CoSe2 as a carrier to generate Co2B in addition to carbon-based products. The catalytic activity of Co2B was significantly increased thanks to the strong combined influence between Co2B and CoSe2 nanosheets. In addition to carbon-based products, Guo et al. [81] used CoSe2 as a carrier to generate Co2B. Because of the powerful coupled effects that occur when Co2B and CoSe2 nanosheets interact with one another, the activity of Co2B has been improved. A self-supporting boride catalyst is an additional type of metal boride-supported compound. This type of catalyst is generated in situ on a 3D substrate. Because mainstream boride catalysts are typically powders, in order to manufacture electrodes, it is necessary to create a suspension of the catalyst in a liquid collector such as a gas chromatograph (GC) and then add pricey binders to the suspension so that it will be more stable [83]. The addition of polymer binder increases the electrocatalyst's series resistance, inhibiting effective electron diffusion and partially obscuring the active catalytic site. A self-sustaining boride catalyst can effectively handle the issue [84]. Therefore, the TMBs efficiency can be further enhanced by creating metal boride-supported compounds. These compounds take advantage of the beneficial characteristics of carrier materials, such as high conductivity and good dispersion of C-based materials, as well as the self-supporting characteristics of the 3D substrates, which have high stability. 4 Noble-metal-free based electrocatalysts for OER Ir, Ru, and Rh-based catalysts outperform all other metal-based catalysts on what concerns OER catalytic activity, with Ru > Ir > Rh being the catalyst with the lowest OER activity [85]. However, the application of noble-metal elements as catalysts for OER is hindered not only by a lack of resources but also by expensive pricing and poor stability. This is even though noble-metal elements are the best catalysts for OER. Therefore, it is not easy to use as many noble metal catalysts, and it is challenging to locate non-noble materials that work as well [86]. Transition metal-based OER catalysts are potential alternatives because the oxygen-evolving complex contains structurally and chemically active sites [87]. The complete process of water splitting is also made more viable by transition-metal elements' properties [88,89]. Co oxides are one of the first to be utilized as an OER catalyst in an alkaline medium, making them one of the best transition-metal-based catalysts. This is due to their excellent stability as well as their one-of-a-kind 3D electronic topologies [90]. Despite cobalt oxides' outstanding stability and catalytic activity, further research has discovered that they still fall short of noble metal oxides. Then, it is shown that doped or mixed oxides can cause synergistic effects via intra-component electronic interactions [91]. Using a straightforward one-pot thermal treatment approach, Jin et al. created CoOx@CN, demonstrating superior catalytic activity over CO oxides for oxygen evolution and reduction reactions (Fig. 6 ) [92]. TMOs are responsible for the surface-active sites capable of catalyzing the OER. The ongoing oxidation of the metal's active site is the oxygen evolution mechanism's process. However, the formation of the hydroxyl peroxide by metal cations restricts the oxygen evolution rate, which reflects the abundance of transition metal oxides [93, 94]. Therefore, as improved OER electrocatalysts, a variety of TMO catalysts, including TMOs/N-doped carbon hybrids [95], NixCo3-xO4 [96], Co-Fe-O/rGO [97], Ni-Fe oxide [98], MxMn3-xO4 (M: divalent metals) [99], and others, can be employed. The aforementioned metal oxides exhibit strong electrocatalytic properties for OER, although spinel's phase transition during oxygen evolution presents a challenge. The material's inherent conductivity will rise if oxides are replaced with chalcogenides (sulfides, selenides, or tellurides). The remarkable electronic structures and physical characteristics of transition-metal chalcogenides, such as their high conductivity, magnetic properties, and half-metallicity, are well known [100,101]. Recently, it has come to everyone's attention that transition metal phosphides are incredibly efficient and abundant catalysts for the HER and the OER [102,103]. Thin-film phosphidation is used to create a variety of highly active and very effective transition metal phosphide electrodes that serve as electrocatalysts for the HER and OER [104]. In summary, metal phosphides have demonstrated significant promise in both HER and OER. Transition metal and metal phosphide catalysts can increase their OER activity; however, it is essential to take into account that with prolonged usage, their performance will quickly decline [105]. 5 Carbon-based electrocatalysts for OER Metal-based catalysts have a wide variety of drawbacks, the most common of which are interference from impurities, limited selectivity, poor stability, and ambiguous active sites. Because of this, discovering an OER catalyst that has a high enough activity, a more significant number of electrocatalytic active sites, a larger specific surface area, and a long-lasting lifespan will be particularly challenging [106]. Carbon-based materials doped with phosphorus, bromine, nitrogen, and sulfur are good conductors that show chemical inertness in acidic or alkaline electrolytes. These materials have been extensively researched and are widely used in electric catalytic reactions [107]. Promising electrocatalysts can be made from carbon-based materials, and their catalytic activity can be significantly increased by doping them with nitrogen or boron. Because nitrogen is present, N-doped carbon has more active sites, a higher density of defects, and a higher level of electrochemical activity [108]. Because of their improved electronic properties, N-doped catalysts in the carbon network hold promise for many applications, such as OER/ORR catalysts in fuel cell systems [109]. For instance, nitrogen-doped carbon nanomaterials are the best non-metal OER catalysts, with current densities of up to 10 mA cm−2 at 0.38 V in alkaline solutions. This value is on par with catalysts containing iridium and cobalt oxide. Because the produced O2 gas was found at an onset potential, it was clear that the N/C catalyst has OER activity [110]. Because of the initial properties of carbon nanotubes and the relationship between the number of walls and their respective OER activities, it was predicted that as the number of walls increased, the OER activity would also increase. This prediction was based on the fact that the outer wall was in charge of OER and the inner wall's job was to speed up the electron transfer rate. However, as dc bias influence has decreased, the number of walls has increased with a corresponding decrease in OER activity [111]. Later, several researchers hypothesized that MWCNT has a dual function with an outside wall and an interior wall after successfully using it as a high-efficiency electrocatalyst in OER without any treatment [112]. It was also first suggested that MWCNTs' surfaces may be oxidized to produce oxygen-containing groups and defect sites that could dope the heteroatoms and obtain an unforeseen high OER catalytic activity [113]. A significant catalyst has also been demonstrated for the composite of CNTs and other nanomaterials [114]. Mainly because of hexagonal boron nitride's (h-BN) distinct graphene-like structure and its interaction with CNTs, the composites display outstanding OER electrocatalytic activity and possess more excellent stability than the most advanced Pt/C catalyst [115]. Besides, graphene-based compounds like graphene, graphene-doped materials, or materials that resemble graphene also show good OER activity [116]. For example, Chen et al. created an N, O-dual doped graphene-CNT hydrogel film with remarkable electrochemical endurance due to the increased surface area and the number of active sites. Moreover, the Tafel slope was approximately 141 mV dec−1, albeit slightly higher, indicating that OER dynamics must be addressed. A more active site may also aid in this regard [117]. As was already said, carbon-based materials have higher electron conductivity than metal oxide-based OER catalysts and perform better electrochemically. They can also be produced in large quantities due to cheaper manufacturing costs [118]. Additionally, by preventing the release of metal ions, such metal-free catalysts might lessen their influence on the environment [86]. 6 Conclusions and future perspectives With fuel cells and water electrolysis to generate hydrogen as the two primary hydrogen energy sources, creating highly effective materials to electrocatalyze water splitting is essential for achieving high conversion efficiencies. Due to their high cost and scarcity of resources, the use of rare precious metal catalysts has hindered the smooth development of these two solutions. As a result, the main issue to be solved is creating effective and affordable non-noble metal and non-metallic catalysts. Due to their innate catalytic character, over the last few years, the TMBs have become a class of unique OER electrocatalysts. Although they have been shown to be promising OER catalysts, there is still a long way to go before they can be used in real life. This is because (i) recent research has concentrated on performance enhancement. However, it is still unclear how TMBs work as OER catalysts. (ii) the most abundant electrolyte on Earth is salt water. Hence simulating seawater conditions for electrolysis research is an essential step in real-world electrolysis applications, where the existing catalysts are mainly employed for HER and OER under acidic or alkaline conditions, respectively. (iii) The crucial future research area is the creation of multifunctional catalysts. It is now possible to catalyze multiple reaction processes at the same time thanks to the multifunctional catalytic material, which not only lowers the production cost and allows the use of the same catalyst for various processes. These processes include HER, OER, and ORR reactions [119]. In the near future, electrolysis will likely enable hydrogen to become a regular energy source. To summarize, efforts made in the future to develop high-activity OER catalysts should emphasize composition, dynamic structures, and purity. Therefore, creating an effective, stable, economical, and environmentally friendly electrocatalyst is a pressing task. In this instance, the electrocatalyst can be made to function more effectively by doping conductive materials, introducing foreign components, and altering their shape. Most critically, most research on non-precious electrocatalyst design has concentrated on creating HER catalysts for acidic environments. However, OER catalysts are utilized in alkaline settings due to their thermodynamic convenience, which may result in reduced efficiency and incompatibility between the two catalyst types. Therefore, additional research on combining HER and OER catalysts should be done to construct more developed catalysts with outstanding electrocatalytic performance, thus ensuring that the requirements for future practical applications are met. coredata.dc:description: Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is acknowledged as a significant half-reaction in water splitting for long-term hydrogen generation. In this context, developing effective catalysts for OER has thus far been the subject of considerable effort. Owing to their high activity and stability as inexpensive OER electrocatalysts, in addition to non-metals and oxide metals-based oxides considered the standard, metals have attracted a growing interest. The design and synthesis of all types of metal for water oxidation electrocatalysis are succinctly outlined in this review. Besides, some typical uses for these metals are noted. Moreover, the outlook and development trends are explored.
coredata.dc:title: Latest insights on eco-friendly metal based-electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reaction: Challenges, and future perspectives
